description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @kjunlvr2 If you offer places to go and someone says no without any input, don't waste any more energy on that person. Major red flag. Relationships should be a give and take.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @DiskFlexy I don't expect men to always be decisive. I just expect that when you ask someone out, you put effort into planning. This applies to all genders.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @GuyEgregious He didn't include me in the decision-making process, he expected me to do the entire decision making. I hear you, we live in a dangerous world, and we want to make people feel safe, which is why I think offering options offers agency and respects your date's time

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @dumbsausage I hear this but I think adding "If you're busy and can't think of a place, how about xx?" shows that you want them to be comfortable and that you don't expect them to shoulder the responsibility of planning.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @MystiqueHoops @theAnjelGrace So sadly true.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @AngelSinclairxo Yeah, I agree. It's also just a sign of commitment issues. Maybe I'm generalizing but a person who can plan I think is a person who is more likely to handle commitment.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @KevinSmiley17 I think whoever asks the person out, should plan. If you don't want to plan, don't ask someone out. The reason I gendered this in the first place is that I only experience this with cis men. When women and non-binary ask me out, they plan or offer options.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @AngelSinclairxo Little do they know that a lot of women only care about good food too (I mean at least I do). It's such misogyny - the things men tell themselves, so they don't have to take initiative or expend energy planning.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @mom_alexa What are some non-drinking dates you have loved?

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @Parkerluna_ I will also add that the reason I gendered this is that I only experience this with cis men. When women & non-binary people ask me out, they either plan or give me options. And they usually plan nice dates. I'm way more likely to get "Whatever you want" from men.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @Parkerluna_ But the range of responses to this tweet show me that people have different opinions on this. I think I just need to be clearer that planning dates (whether you're a man or woman or neither) is an act of care for me.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @Parkerluna_ I'm more than happy to plan when I ask someone out. I do this when I ask out men, women, & non-binary people. But when someone asks me out & then expects me to plan the entire day w/o any input? It feels disrespectful to my time & leaves me wondering if they just want casual sex

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @ManifestBestYT I'm trying to protect myself from men who are incapable of intimacy and have no interest in anything but casual sex. If you've read my tweets, you'll see that I've been treated badly by men. I have every right to criticize and be discerning.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @ManifestBestYT Ya that doesn't work when you've been raised to ignore red flags and when you date in the city filled with garbage men. That's why I'm asking about more subtle red flags. So, I don't waste my time.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @theAnjelGrace Prolly not a bad strategy

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @SteveLarsonBRT Ya I hear that. I date a lot of ND men & I try to have compassion but often they don't have compassion for my ED, so I'm less empathic. General rule: if you ask someone out, offer 2 to 3 options for places & then ask them to decide. If you struggle to plan, ask a friend for help

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @theAnjelGrace I think a lot of people forget that dating requires energy, and just want to see what happens without putting int effort. It's boring. I want to learn about new spots, inspired by someone else's passion for life

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @ali_b_where That's my fear

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @JonathanDPDX Choices are great, definitely a green flag for me. It shows care and initiative.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @theAnjelGrace I agree with this. Where are you located? Maybe this is a problem in New York or any city where people are regularly going on dates. But yeah men who don't take iniative are usually men who don't know what they want or only want something 'casual' or whatever that means to them.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: Also thank you so much for all the responses. I appreciate them all

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @slooterman That make sense. Definitely in terms of sensory issues.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @ITLStaff All planning, regardless of whether it's for pleasure or not, is work. It requires parts of our brain that drain of us energy.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @slooterman That maybe true, especially on 1st date, but I also feel its misogyny. Cis men expecting women to plan b/c they have no clue how much work is to curate a night b/c it's always been done for them. Perhaps I'm bitter but I've had men ghost me after I asked them to plan a night

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @imgooley01 Asking for their opinion is nice but it's also nice to respect someone's time. Planning is work. You can always say: 'Do you have a fav place? If not, would you like go to x place'

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @PeripheralMinds I suppose that's kind and okay for the first date. But I think a lot of women, including myself, don't find planning comfortable since we do so much of it in our day-to-day lives.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @ITLStaff But that puts more pressure on your date and asks them to do more work. I think offering options allows the person to pick a place they feel safe going to while also not putting all the responsibility on them.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @itsalisonsparks That's perfectly fine. Equal input spreads responsibility fairly.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @Magnus919 That would require he to haved asked questions. Not just 'where should we go'

name: Reese Piper

name: Reese Piper

name: Reese Piper

tweet: @hyggewitch @NatashaSalad420 I think the key is to offer options. This way you don't put too much stress on someone to plan while also giving them control.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @NatashaSalad420 The nicest and sexiest thing a person can do for me is tell me when and where to be. But they don't know that planning is tough for me.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @strippedbysia Do you notice personality or attachment differences in men who plan vs men who don't? Like are men who don't plan more likely to be avoidant or only interested in casual sex?

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: If someone asked you out for a drink on a dating app and then asked, 'where should we go?" would you still go out with them? I'm so sick of men asking me to plan dates. You asked me out, you plan. Am I too harsh? Or is a red flag that someone has no clue how to plan a date?

name: Reese Piper

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @hannahexclamat I hired an executive functioning coach three years and I thought she would give me tips that she's picked up from other patients. It's so much complicated than that. It's taken us this long to finally create a system that works for me.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @hannahexclamat Not the point of your tweet but general tips on how to improve your ADHD or executive functioning don't work. What we need to stay calm, focused and productive is dependent on your trauma, whether you can switch b/w tasks, and how much stimulation you need. It's very personal.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @Joosey @amberdreamnyc If someone is great but sex is meh, why not just stay close friends and find a romantic partner that can fill your sexual needs?

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @Joosey @amberdreamnyc I hear both of you but I'm struggling to understand the line b/w friendship & romantic relationships without much sex. I have very close friends, one who lives with me and shares her day-to-day with me, but we don't cuddle or have sex.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: I find it amazing how many people in my attachment groups suggest waiting until you're in a relationship to have sex. How do you know you want to invest in someone if you haven't had sex?

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @khiahstrachan It's was so giod. Easy to read, digestable, not overly literary, and such a fanscinating journey

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @sapiotextual Miss you too!

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: I just finished 'Eleanor Oliphant Is Completely Fine' & loved it! Some have been wondering if the main character is autistic, and she may be. But it's less about neurodivergence and more about loneliness, trauma, and the power of friendship. Worth a read. https://t.co/JJ5V2Zdf9K

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @CheMusEducator @EricMGarcia @Tmbritti The article was about Kathy Griffen so not a deep dive into Sia's mind. Both I believe are trying to repair their reputation. All they need to do is ask how they can do better

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @EricMGarcia @Tmbritti Ah I didn't read the Times article! Definitely missed that. The Times should be able to hold more nuance. name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi

name: Reese Piper

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @treynormal Omg Trey

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @popcravv @ArielRoseV The movie should have been cancelled and shouldn't be in theatres anywhere. It's harmful to autistic people. I just don't believe piling on her is going to get her to see the damage she caused. You can still love her and demand she do better.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @popcravv @ArielRoseV I agree with @ArielRoseV . When you commit harm, you should take a step back and ask how you can do better. People who have been harmed should take center stage. Sia should ask how she can repair this.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @ArielRoseV @murderhornet212 My original tweet demanded that she do better and acknowlged the harm she caused. I'm not defending her or her movie. I just believe we should have compassion for people who commit harm. It's how we heal.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @BucolicUtopia I think how Sia reacted is disgusting, the movie was disgusting. It's just that I've struggled with sucidal thoughts for years and it's triggering to see people say 'who cares'. Idk, maybe I'm wrong but I believe people who commit harm still deserve compassion.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @EricMGarcia Is it possible to hate the movie, be furious about how she reacted, while still having compassion for her sucidal ideation? It's gross that Kathy and her fans aren't acknowleding how damaging Music is. But as someone who has been sucidal, it's tough to hear 'I don't care'

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @CarnageAmerican That still doesn't mean she deserves to die. People who harm also deserve compassion. Replicating America's current "you did a bad thing & can never change & deserve to rot in hell' system is not going to help build a better world for autistic people.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @ketlacedlove @siafurlerfan_ Did Sia write that? No, she didn't. The writer took her quote and put it into their own context. I'm not standing up for her, I'm angry about what she did, I just don't understand how pouncing on her is going to get her to suddenly take accountability.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @ketlacedlove @siafurlerfan_ I did read it. 3 times. And I'm well aware that Sia didn't write the headline. Nor was most of the piece focused on how she's feeling now. It's just a compilation of quotes. She could be blaming autistic people for her problems, but we don't have enough info to assume that

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @CarnageAmerican She was horrid but she doesn't deserve to die (she has attempting suicide 3 times before). Instead of rejoicing in her pain we should be telling her and other people who made this how they can do better.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @ketlacedlove @siafurlerfan_ It's infuriating that she hasn't taken responsibility, but as someone who also struggles with suicide ideation, it's not great to see the words victim blaming next to suicide. All that does is a feed a system where people think their mental issues aren't 'real'

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @ketlacedlove @siafurlerfan_ Nowhere in the article did she blame her suicide ideation on backlash. The piece is just a bunch of quotes put together, not a deep dive into her mind. She may feel that way but it's not clear.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @ketlacedlove @siafurlerfan_ How about we don't say someone is playing the victim when they voice their mental health concerns? Since lots of autistic people struggle with suicide ideation, I don't see how this idea is helpful. She should apologize and do better, but no one should minimize the desire to die

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @murderhornet212 No, you're right, she hasn't. But waking up to thousands of comments that are laughing at her suicide struggles is not going to push her to do so. We can be sorry she's going through this while demanding that she do better. It's not one or the other.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @murderhornet212 Yes that's where Twitter may go. But I don't believe anyone should be in jail forever. We can live in a world with nuance. Showing empathy might actually get her to empathize with the people she harmed.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @murderhornet212 Ya I hear that but we are adults with the ability to understand the damage she caused, demand that she do better, while also having compassion. This black and white, cancel culture mentality just replicates neurotypical you can only be good or bad thinking

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @murderhornet212 If you scroll through the quote tweets on the original post you'll see a bunch of comments saying 'oh well she should have thought of that before.' All that does it create a more hostile world for people to express their struggles with sucidial ideation.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @murderhornet212 Sia has attempted suicide 3 times (on top of having other issues that auties have like Elhers Danos &  being unable to show her face). There's no doubt that Music caused damage, but how does minimizing her struggles help autistic people? As so many struggle with similar problems

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @murderhornet212 Yes, she should. I doubt that all the comments telling her that her suicidal ideation doesn't matter will help tho. So many people have a ton of internalized ableism to work through. She's not an outlier, just part of a fucked up system.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: No one should ever say that someone deserves to be sucidial. Especially since sucide is a huge problem for autistic people. Challenge her to do better, push Hollywood to fund better films, write your own scripts. Do something instead of rejoicing about someone's pain.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: You can be angry with Sia, upset about the damage Music caused, and still feel compassion for her. She didn't make this movie alone and was most likely influenced by an industry that profits from dehumanizing depictions of autism. I also suspect she's on the spectrum. https://t.co/YhaHks35P5

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @zoeyyluna Because lesbians love talking and sharing trauma

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: This is such bullshit and dehumanizing. It insinuates that autistic people don't want or need connection. SPD is a symptom of autism and is part of the reason why autistic people struggle with relationships.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: Just read this article about people who want to make sensory processing its own disorder, separate from autism, because 'kids with just SPD want to socialize but can't bear it.' Unlike autistic kids who apparently hate everyone but themselves.  https://t.co/VeFySNJu3b

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: If autism was defined by difficulty processing stimuli, planning and organizing, and moving your body through the world (with an understanding that these can all make interacting with people strenuous) than more people would feel comfortable embracing their diagnosis.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: Researchers carry this weird believe that autistic people simply don't want to socialize. That they're sociopathic aliens born without need for love & connection. It's rare that doctors frame social issues in autism as a manifestation of sensory difficulties.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: While not exactly scientific, this reddit thread goes into how Claritin or Allegra might help relieve horrific PMDD symptoms. Since doctors refuse to study women's bodies, anecdotal discussions are often the best source of information. https://t.co/2fxwDkA4iz

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: Last night I went down the PMDD rabbit hole, and while research is sparse, it seems some people have found relief after taking antihistamines. Apparently too much histamine activates your nervous system which in turn aggravates your hormonal fluctuations. Fascinating.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: People with executive dysfunction can't change. That's why it's a disability. We may be able to learn how to incorporate cleaning into a set routine. But there'll never be a day where we'll wake up and be able to clean and cook without struggle. Our brains aren't wired that way.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet:
I've been having issues w my roomies about my lack of cleaning, the pile of dishes in the sick and my shit strewn across our apartment. In the past, I would have apologized profusely, promised I'd change. But now? I just send them a copy of my article.
https://t.co/iPUXn60nvo

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: Any New Zealanders open to talking about the high suicide rates & loneliness across the islands? I'm writing about visiting NZ in my memoir, about how I felt empty and sad rather than connected to nature as I had hopped. But I'd like to put my experience within a larger context

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: Give up the story of your parents. They'll never be the people who can love and care for you the way you deserve. Let them go and throw your energy into relationships that can sustain you. Your heart will keep breaking otherwise.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: This also delves into empathy. That in order to empathize with others you need a proper sense of your own body (so you know that you feel differently from others). Autistic people get called sociopaths for lack of tom, but it may be as simple as lack of bodily awareness.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: It's something to think about for autism. If autistic people don't understand why they perceive the world differently, then they're more likely to reject their experiences and turn away from their bodies.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: I love this paper by @manos_tsakiri. Its dense but it describes how sense of self is reliant on the ability to understand how we process our sensory world. That in order to feel at home in our bodies, we have to understand how our perceptions make us feel https://t.co/UHXCZ9mtph

tweet: Perhaps I should be more open to educating romantic interests. I'm more willingly with friends and most people don't understand that executive dysfunction is a disability after all. But it's just such a turn off when you have to fight to be seen.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: I've walked away from potential romantic relationships because they've struggle to understand executive difficulties. E.G "How hard can it be to wash your dishes?" or "I think it's rude and disrespectful when people don't show up on time." https://t.co/PCAr7jFsxh

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: The mental health dip after I ovulate is like whiplash. I go from loving myself and feeling content with my life to thinking heroin might be a decent option. The evidence is spotty but it seems neurodivergent women are more prone to PMDD. Any theories on why?

name: Reese Piper

tweet: "A world built on speed, productivity, more, more, more! and far too few bathrooms does not consider or care for the actual bodies we live in. In other words, ableism affects all of us, whether we consider ourselves disabled or not."

tweet: @pasteldreamgirl Thanks for the feedback. I'm not trying to assume based on my own personal experience. Rather I'm questioning whether the assumption that one type of work is more dangerous than the other is fair to make since danger means different things to different people.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @tilliananderson @HellcatAzura I've been grabbed by the crotch and had far worse things done to me in clubs. I still found it more palatable than the dysmorphia I got when I did online work. Again just my personal experience

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @tilliananderson @HellcatAzura I hear that...which is why the concept of risk varies from person to person. I don't think there should be blanket statement. But again this is just my opinion

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @tilliananderson @HellcatAzura This is just me and difficult to say but I would rather deal with a customer pushing my boundaries than having to work day in and day out. Working constantly is more harmful to my well-being than interpersonal conflict

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @tilliananderson @HellcatAzura I guess my interest in this is the idea that verbal and physical assault is more damaging than other types of harms (the permanent record of porn; less financial stability of online work; the constant need to post post post to build an online presence)

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: I fear stating that in-person work is riskier contributes more stigma to strippers and escorts. It gives the impression that clubs & brothels are 'dirty' while the Onlyfans is 'clean'. Still in-person involves harm. Is it fair to assume that migrating online will protect us?

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: As a culture, I don't think we have empathy for the drug-using sex worker trying to giver her family a better life. Not yet at least. Still #MAIDNetflix is worth a watch and I'm excited to read the memoir it was based off of now. Just watch with caution.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: I would have escaped...but I would've needed to strip to do so, so I could have time off in-between work. Lots of people use sex work to leave abusive dynamics & lots of people use drugs to manage, but I doubt that story would ever get a Netflix deal.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: If I had grown up in poverty like the main character, I wouldn't have been able to escape an abusive relationship with 'regular' work. My disability wouldn't have allowed me to clean different houses all day & then take care of a baby all night. Not without Adderall or Oxies

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: But I think the show has been so successful b/c it portrays a woman who escaped with back-bending round-the-clock work without the use of drugs or sex work. It's based on a true story but its success is rooted in ableism and the value we place on productivity

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: I enjoyed #MAIDNetflix about a young mother who starts cleaning homes to extract herself from an abusive man. Parts of the show hit hard and felt real: the back-and-forth tug of toxic relationships, the 'helpful' father who can't see the control inflicted on his daughter

name: Reese Piper

tweet: The current rhetoric on neurodivergence will have you believe you either have autism autism or bpd, ocd or bipolar, PTSD or adhd. This all or nothing, either or approach is why people go undiagnosed. All these conditions overlap, they interact with our messy lives

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: The counselor sent me home. Told me this was my decision to make but I had to be certain because there was no going back. At 9 weeks, I took the pill and terminated in my house.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: Most are certain about their decision to abort. I wasn't. I was living in a fantasy where I believed a baby would heal me. Thank god I only had to drive 20 mins to a clinic and that a counselor was there to hear my story. If there had obstacles, I don't know if I would've went.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: I found out at 6 weeks and up until 8 weeks, I planned on keeping the baby. I believed having a baby would solve our problems or at least make him treat me better. It was only after a particularly nasty fight that I drove to Planned Parenthood to discuss my options.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: Terminating my pregnancy was the hardest decision I ever made. I was deeply attached to an abusive, mentally unstable man and I couldn't help but hope that a baby would fix our problems. Choosing to abort was the first healthy decision I made in my 5 year toxic relationship.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: Nonfiction writers have to balance the ethics of telling people's stories that intersect with our own. It will hurt my family when I capture their story, and so, I only reveal the parts that have become my history b/c it would be too violating to have their entire lives disected

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: If you can't create fictional characters and lives, then write nonfiction. If you can't even change basic details, then you have no business being a writer. Your art is not more important than people's lives. She hurt these people. Isn't that enough for this to be unethical?

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: Also, the dude DIED. Possibly from suicide. Imagine being portrayed as creepy, rapist when you weren't. Not all men who date young women are terrible, and neither are the women always hapless, but of course this narrative went viral. It's something we all want to believe.

name: Reese Piper

tweet: Scrolling through my feed. I'm disturbed by how many people are defending the author of Cat Person. If  a writer took your life experiences, instilled abuse into your story, portrayed you as a naive victim, and then turned around and made six figures off of it, you'd be livid.

name: Reese Piper

name: Reese Piper

tweet: @slooterman In the way that sex workers perform hyper-femininity, bales bondmen perform masculinity. But in jobs like waitressing and flight attendants and nursing where it's predominately women, the act 'caring' is usually performed by women.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @slooterman I would say that emotional labor isn't just the work of women. The original definition was designed to capture how men & women in service jobs perform gender to get clients to feel like the experience is natural.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: I wrote about it below. The various levels of emotional labor and the impact it has on the sense of self. https://t.co/9vTWqRS300 https://t.co/FoqQ3c4unI

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: It's a gendered performance but it is not just the work of women. Car salesmen, for example, perform emotional labor. Bales bondmen also perform anger and traits of hypermasculinity to get people to fork over their money.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: When Emotional Labor is used as a term to describe interactions b/w men and women it erases the experiences of working-class people. Emotional labor is supposed to capture how men & women manage and suppress their own feelings to draw clients into the right mood to spend money. https://t.co/gY4Rb1IG5q

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @ImpemboGanecue @prolepeach I'm a disabled person who has been able to afford a maid because of sex work. Disability means a lot of things and yes many are poor but some aren't.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @MommyBiggerDick @prolepeach I don't think anyone should brag about paying for a maid and people should be aware of how that person is being paid and conditiom they're working in but they are indeed people who need help to function.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @MommyBiggerDick @prolepeach This is the kinda of abelist talk that I fear when this conversation comes up. Lots of people, including myself, with autism & adhd, can physically clean up but cannot do so sometimes because functioning ability wanes.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: Today's been such a mess of a day. Been trying to edit my work in the midst of finding out details that my ex's sister was brutally murdered. Nothing I write is making any kind of sense. Send me pics of your pets!

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @prolepeach But how do we deal with people who cannot clean up after themselves? It's not just an indivudal issue. There's a whole class of disabled people who need day to day support. How do we approach this while also acknolwedging conditions?

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @prolepeach My friend and I debate this all the time. We both have adhd and could benefit from help cleaning up. The idea that you should be able to clean up after yourselves and not need help is of course deeply abelist but maid conditions are abhorrent. It's complicated

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @prolepeach Lot of people with disabilities day-to-day lives can be drastically improved with maids and many won't hire them because of this. If you pay them individually & not through an agency does this remedy this? Obv not so black and white.

name: Reese Piper

name: Reese Piper

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: Happy Autism Acceptance month. Let's not spend this month debating whether it's a disease or a gift, a burden or a joy. Let's instead talk about the multitude of ways autism intersects with various identities. Below are my two essays that delve into this.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: If I was to host a monthly autistic women and non-binary meet up in New York this summer would people be interested? (For formally diagnosed, self-diagnosed, and questioning)

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @JohnDeVore I also want to add: that I have cried many many times over customers coming into the club and not spending money. Nights were I made as little as 20 dollars or went home in debt after a grueling 10 hour shift in heels. Understand it from our perspective.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @JohnDeVore It's great you're writing about addiction. As someone who also struggles with alcohol too, I understand the way all nightlife can feed that beast. But strip clubs are businesses and the dancers are there to make money.  That doesn't make us heartless. It makes us human.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @JohnDeVore I'm sorry that you were hurting. Break ups are awful.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @JohnDeVore Strippers don't work for free, we actually pay to work and enter each shift in debt.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @JohnDeVore " A dancer tried to comfort me by asking me to buy her a drink and I told her I was broke, I was broken, what am I doing? It's not appropriate to go into a place of business and not spend money on the workers. Would you go to restaurant and sit down and not eat?

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @JohnDeVore As someone who has worked in strip clubs for over 5 years, I'm telling you that lines "Strip clubs can be fun the way novocaine is fun" are extremely harmful. Strippers, while of course are no angels, who like all humans are bad and good, don't need any more trash thrown on us.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @JohnDeVore Men have cried on my lap in clubs, sometimes I have cared and offered support. Sometimes I had no capacity to because I'm human and I have my own life and issues and I just need to pay my bills. Strippers don't owe you anything.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @JohnDeVore Many of the queen's strip clubs have egregious labor practices, which alongside customers coming in and thinking it's okay not to spend money (which is loitering) can impede on a worker's ability to care. Our jobs are not to rescue you, they are to provide a service

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @JohnDeVore Congratulating on further stigmatizing a profession of mostly women who are already struggling more than ever due to the pandemic.

name: Reese Piper

tweet: As I've said many times before, men who are ashamed of their desire to visit sex workers, particularly sex workers of color, are the most dangerous. They believe they deserve sex for free and are humiliated that they have to pay women they consider beneath them for it

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: I want to clarify- it's unclear if these women were sex workers and it's doubtful any of their friends or family will claim that identity, but the mainstream belief that Asian massage parlors offer sex seemed (and the disgust of that/fear of diseases) to have fueled this attack.

name: Reese Piper

tweet: Reading more now. It's not clear if it was a massage parlors that offered more; not sure if that will be covered up.  But the shooters certainly thought so. He apparently said he had a sex addiction and want to eliminate his temptation for 'these places' https://t.co/bZ2q2SIkBb

name: Reese Piper

tweet: Scrolling through Twitter, I'm not seeing any mention of the fact that these women were sex workers. Erasing this in fear of victim blaming will only cause more harm. We have to talk about the consequences of criminalization.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: It's also not clear if any of these workers were migrants but there is a belief that most workers in massage parlors are migrants and that belief is strong enough to spread disgust.

name: Reese Piper

tweet: Criminalizing massage parlors sends a message to the world that massage parlor workers are criminals, and thus, less than human. This added in with the belief that migrant sex workers spread diseases and a harmful to society.

name: Reese Piper

tweet: @TiiaAurora Yes but a lot of autistic people need help with executive dysfunction and can't receive it b/c it's not seen as a core symptom of autism (even though research says otherwise). There's no reason that various forms of support can't exist if it's under one spectrum

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: I know many may disagree but I don't see any value in continuing to separate ADHD and Autism. I think it should merge them into one neurodivergent spectrum with clusters of various ways it can manifest.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: Attempts to draw lines b/w ADHD & Autism only erase common traits of neurodivergence. Someone diagnosed with ADHD might not see their socially difficulties. Someone diagnosed with Autism may not see their poor working memory and careless mistakes as part of their disability

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet:
- Autistics can be hyposensitive or hypersensitive (or waffle b/w both). 
- Many want routines but are unable to create them b/c executive dysfunction. 
- Autistic people have problems with working memory. 
- Autistic people struggle with impulsivity

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: There's been a Venn Diagram floating around Facebook about the differences between ADHD & Autism, defining ADHD as impulsive, chaotic, hypo-sensitive & autism as having strict routines, poor cues, hyper-sensitive. All of the traits listed below are documented traits of autism https://t.co/2TKYg7bGiC

tweet: Issues with TOM is a trauma response (you need to be treated as an individual to understand others). The fact that autistics struggle with it reveals more about the layers of codependency & dysfunction in many of  our families from generations of ableism than of faulty wiring.

name: Reese Piper

name: Reese Piper

tweet: Film production companies are well aware that sex work is seen as otherwordly and use it to touch on our innate desire to escape into secret spheres. Producing shows about escorts and strippers in their heightened moments, showcasing their wild and salacious adventures

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: There is an insidious notion that lingers in moves and shows about sex work: that it's radically different from other working-class jobs; an industry that irrevocably changes the people who enter it.

name: Reese Piper

tweet: I've been watching a lot of Shameless & I wrote about why it's the most accurate portrait of sex work. Many of the characters dip in and out of the industry, which is treated as an essential part of daily life in poor America https://t.co/or5xZG7rO4 https://t.co/yYa13tewlk

name: Reese Piper

tweet: The same impulse that drives poor and working class women to sell Mary Kay and Avon - learn confidence thru sales, an escape from shitty circumstances, join a community of women - is the same impulse that drives women into sex work

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @littlehux Ah that makes sense! How does it impact/cause seizures?

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @littlehux Ya that lines up with my experience. I have big ones, and little fainting episodes, all have either occurred on edibles or when I was emotionally or physically exhausted, so yeah as a byproduct of overstimulation/masking. What is HeDS?

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: My non-epileptic seizures were brushed aside as inexplicable, but the research was there that it could be a byproduct of autism. I've said this before, but we need to look at autism as something that creates differences in how the brain and body operate, not just in socializing

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: This idea that autism primarily affects social abilities creates a vacuum of symptoms. This article suggests that "16.9% of the children & young adults with non-epileptic seizures also had ASD, with (50%) of these undiagnosed with ASD before referral." https://t.co/KmjUOaIFb0.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: If you look up nonepileptic seizures (which is known as PNES) article after article will say, "There are no research studies available on the epidemiological, medical, or genetic risk factors for childhood PNES."...But the comorbidity of seizures and autism is well established

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @Arielle_Ivy Yeah, that's true! If it makes any sense, I just finished the Root of Evil podcast (very heavy tw on child abuse), but it covers how this gets passed down..so that's where my thoughts are, and why I'm so focused on this https://t.co/A8eKcj6uB8

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @Arielle_Ivy Ah well, I'm sorry if it came off as an attack. I was looking at it through the lens of generational trauma, as child sexualization gets passed down, from family to family. I wasn't really interested in agreeing or disagreeing but having a discussion on sexualizaion of children

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @Arielle_Ivy It's fine to disagree, but that's where my thoughts are

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @Arielle_Ivy That's not what I'm saying. I'm pointing out another layer that's part of the problem. Personally, I don't think we can discuss the sexualization of girls without discussing the sexualization of boys, and how trauma gets reenacted. I don't believe they can exist separately

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @Arielle_Ivy I'm not rerouting, I'm merely coloring in the original idea. Adding to it.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @Arielle_Ivy Many of the men in my family were molested as children. And many of those men grew up to wreak havoc on their families...and I imagine sexualized little girls too. There's a bigger picture of abuse happening

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @Arielle_Ivy That there's more to the story than adult men sexualize little girls. Trauma runs in circles and it's important if we want to understand child sexualization that we understand that it's not rare for boys to be molested

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @Arielle_Ivy You can't claim that you know that as fact - fact doesn't exist abuse reporting. I have agreed with you that girls are sexualized more in public, but there is something interesting happening, when men don't have empathy with women's struggles, even though many of them are victims

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @Arielle_Ivy There's no point in engaging if you automatically think your right. I'm open to discussion, but we have to both be open to each other's ideas.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @Arielle_Ivy You and I know both know that these stats cannot be relied upon, especially when we're talking about children reporting abuse against possible relatives, especially when we're talking about boys reporting b/c of masculinity

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @Arielle_Ivy Yes, but when you are molested you are sexualized. I'm not arguing against your point. I'm just saying that boys are sexualized as children at very high rates through contact, and many of these same boys grow up to sexualize other children

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @Arielle_Ivy @misslolahunt I don't know....I think perhaps in day-to-day interactions (in public, in front of others, yes) but child molestation rates I imagine are 50/50. Look at what just happened with the boy scouts

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @Arielle_Ivy @misslolahunt This is so interesting, because it's true, but young boys are also sexualized by adult men and women, and exploited. I wonder where the disconnect is

tweet: I'm suspect of any 'condition' that claims autistic people cannot feel or understand something. The way we interact with people and the way people interact with us is profoundly different than neurotypicals.

tweet: I think alexithymia, which is the inability to identify your emotions, is less about emotional awareness and more about enmeshment. I struggle to distinguish my feelings from others and put a boundary between other people's emotions and mine. Which I think is common for autistics

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: There will never be a clear profile for autism or other neurodivergent conditions like dyslexia. It's not like blood pressure. It interacts with the world around you, your class, your gender, your race, the support you have. But that doesn't make it fake. It just makes it varied.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: Autism is seen as a disorder that impacts social skills instead of a different processing system that changes how you categorize information and perceive the world. Language is a category. In the same way that autistic people struggle to speak, many struggle to read and write

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: For kids that don't overtly struggle socially, often struggling to read and write is the first sign that they might be neurodivergent. I could never spell in school but not once did that ever raise a flag for autism

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: Good read by @thedalstonyears about if dyslexia should a diagnosis. Although it doesn't address it, dyslexia is connected to autism. Instead of dividing symptoms of neurodivergence into separate conditions, it might be better to put them under 1 umbrella. https://t.co/2sTzH8snrZ

name: Reese Piper

tweet: I didn't include this but emotional labor increases alcoholism, depression, & suicide ideation. I'd like for us to stop using this term to describe gender roles in relationships and instead breathe light into what workers endure to make their customers comfortable enough to spend

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: I wrote this because emotional labor is an invisible & grueling form of labor required in service industries. And  part of why it's invisible is b/c emotional labor is used incorrectly to describe the work women carry in relationships, not how workers interface with the public

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: It's nearly impossible to get a bank loan for a strip club. That means that the only people who can purchase a new club are organized criminals who have 200k in cash or chains like Deja Vu. With bank loans, former strippers could own a club. Strippers could collectivize.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: Make your own decision about the misclassification debate but I think there are other ways to advocate for labor rights than lawsuits (I'm not shaming lawsuits. Get the money you're owed from the club, but let's state the facts: lawsuits don't change shitty conditions).

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: How can we fight for proper employment classification if dancers are still being criminalized by laws that imprison full-service workers? How can we even have this debate without first dealing with the fact that clubs are regularly raided by vice squads?

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: Lastly, if clubs will be monitored by OSHA or other government entities like other industries, does that mean the government will be more involved in our jobs.? Pole dancing is legal but we all know that lap dancing is a grey area (and that fssw is happening in some clubs)

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: If clubs have to pay all dancers a wage, they will most likely hire fewer dancers. Some dancers would prefer this (who likes working on a floor flooded with dancers?) But that also means managers will be far more selective about who gets hired, favoring skinny, younger, whiter.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: The more official we become, the more legal our job becomes, the less accessible it will be for people who aren't 'legal'. The industry is a lifeline for undocumented people. If clubs have to maintain proper employee paperwork, then they most likely not hire workers w/o papers.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: While we are employees, it's a pretty low stakes job. We can chill with our friends and not make any money. We can show up in a new city and get hired within a few minutes. Many dancers want to keep the industry underground because they don't want an official 9-5 type job.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: Dancing is a survival job. Many of us have invisible disabilities: autism, ADHD, borderline, depression. The whole reason we dance is to not keep a schedule. And the fear is that if we fight for proper classification, every club could demand we show up 4 days a week

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet:
Cons on fighting against misclassification: 

Walmart workers are properly classified as employees and they still get treated like shit. Many dancers have rightfully questioned whether proper classification would stop managers from abusing their power?

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: As properly classified employees, there would be more accountability for our safety. We would also be guaranteed some kind of wage (which might mean less emotional labor), house fees would be banned, and we could report unsafe working conditions. We could also unionize.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: Dancer deaths are not uncommon. It's a hard, emotionally demanding job. Many of us consume alcohol & drugs so we can perform night after night. Managers have left dancers to die in private rooms & have not been held responsible. (And now dancers are at risk of COVID)

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: That means clubs don't have to provide safe working conditions if we're classified as contractors. Cameras in the champagne room? Slippery floors? Overdosed dancer in the dressing room? Customers w/o masks? Doesn't matter to owners. Why care if they won't be held responsible?

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet:
Pros on fighting against misclassification. 

1) Contractors are not entitled to safe working conditions. When you hire contractors, you don't have to adhere to OSHA guidelines and any harm inflicted at work is not the club's fault

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: So the issue is not whether we want to be employees or contractors. The issue is whether we want to fight against being misclassified as contractors through lawsuits. There are numerous reasons why we should fight for this and there are numerous reasons why we shouldn't.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: Dancers are employees. This is regardless of whether you signed paperwork stating you're an independent contractor, regardless of whether you have to keep a schedule. Even in the divest fuck-all clubs, managers exert too much control over our jobs to be considered contractors

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet:
There's been talk about stripper's rights in the media the past couple of days. A lot of dancers are angry that lawsuits against misclassification are being written as a route to improve working conditions. This is a nuanced, complex issue that I'm going to break below

A thread:

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @LibertarianSlut @alexnpress Technically we are employees, but the majority of strippers don't believe it's in their best interest to fight against misclassification.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: Despite every inch of me that wants to back away from this essay, I'm talking about assault in the club. Why is this so difficult?

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @alexnpress It's nuanced and after dancing for five years I still don't have a clear opinion on it. I tried to capture my thoughts about it below...but there's still much more that goes into how we should approach labor violations. Thanks again for covering this!  https://t.co/QCh9r9JY63

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @alexnpress I want to fight for the right to unionize but it's possible that fighting against misclassification could make the industry inaccessible to undocumented workers and create a bigger class divide between indoor/outdoor sex workers

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @alexnpress Thank you for writing about this! Discussing misclassification is more important now than ever with clubs reopening w/o safety protocols. It's true that the strippers are employees but this issue isn't black and white and that's why it's such a contentious issue among dancers

name: Reese Piper

tweet: @MsReignRose I suppose some swers might think flashing money helps them pull in more clients. Like some dancers wear money on their garter for this reason; but unfortunately with onlyfans it's leading to oversaturation

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @questella It's alright. Some dancers liked it and they of course hired sex workers, but it's an extreme story and I'm still not quite sure why it was brought to screen (highlight working class women or highlight why sw should be criminalize?...) I recomend Jezebel.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: The same goes for autism. Make films that feature autistic characters, don't make films about autism. Treating difference as an heightened other wordly experience the way film treats sex work and disability only reinforces that difference.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: If we want to normalize sex work, we need to portray the industry the way sex workers experience it: as a normal part of our humdrum reality. Weave the stigma we experience into the plot; but understand that overtime the stigma too becomes normal

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: Let the Bella Thorne debacle teach us to stop making movies about sex work. Make films about working class people who happen to be sex workers (like Sean Baker's films do) but don't make sex work the plotline. It leads heightened storylines that aren't grounded in reallity

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @janis_therapy My fear is that by making emotional labor too wide of a definition the impact of working in relational fields gets lost. I use these theories below and I'm mostly interested the impacts of deep acting which I think is becoming more and more common across service sectors

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @janis_therapy Accommodating ignorance & putting aside your feelings for the sake of a relationship defo mimics the type of labor we perform in the club. But is it the same as becoming another person and feigning intimacy and desire for a sale? Should these experiences exist under 1 definition?

name: Reese Piper

tweet: @jmkeep I agree. And, of course, marriage is a job for women (you could argue that's is sex work). But the extra organizational work my sisters pulls in her marriage is different than the intimacy I feign in the club. One is not necessarily harder than the other. Just different.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: The extra work that women do in relationships needs another term. Perhaps executive work? Because lumping household work with the acting, absorbing, and faking of emotions that sex workers, flight attendants, etc erases the experiences of primarily working-class women

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: The extra planning and organizing women do in their relationship is work but it's not emotional labor. The term was coined to define the invisible work that therapists, sales reps, sex workers, flight attendants perform to keep their jobs.

name: Reese Piper

tweet: @JustMind Thanks for the suggestions! People with ADHD are more likely to experience trauma (and trauma can impact executive skills) but ADHD is not a byproduct of trauma - it's a different way of having a brain. But yes I hear good things about EMDR.

name: Reese Piper

tweet: Writing about autism is so painful. Most writing is about what autistic people look like, focusing on a few basic social difficulties, and trying to paint an internal picture of my experience against mainstream perceptions is tiring, to say the least.

tweet: @NeuroRebel The majority of neurodivergent people have executive dysfunction. It's impossible to promote workplace acceptance and hiring without an understanding of how this impacts day to day functioning. I've never been able to maintain a job other than sex work because of this.

name: Reese Piper

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: My psychiatrist charged me 70 dollars for reschelduling our appointment an hour before. He's treating me for executive dysfunction - a disability that makes it difficult to remember appointments - and is still penalizing me. This is how grounded ableism is in our world.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: As the COVID vaccine becomes more of a reality, let's prepare ourselves for a new and vicious wave of vaccine-causes-autism debate

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: The most debilitating (and enjoyable?) aspects of executive dysfunction is the inability to switch between tasks. It feels physically painful to pull away from projects to tackle something mundane like dishes. But, oh, do I love the hyperfocus.

name: Reese Piper

tweet: @janis_therapy Ah I see. My hesistancy with discussing this in terms of cognitive mechanisms is that it's assumed that's is something that triggered rather than a constant, nagging feeling

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: But many dancers (including myself) are on unemployment but the cut off day for PUA, July 31st, is looming closer. Many dancers are planning ahead. While others are simply back in the club because they're bored at home and hungry to get back to work.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: Many of the dancers I spoke to were denied PUA or never heard back from their state governments (many in Florida). One dancer said: “This pandemic is like playing Russian Roulette: We’re gonna get it or we’re not gonna get it, and we’re gonna survive or die. Life goes on.”

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: Stripping is a job that comes with a multitude of risks that, for many, are worth it b/c the job provides an opportunity to make more than minimum wage. Yet, strippers are now making a different set of cost-benefit calculations.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @MxAllanaMae @STRIPPUHANIKA What signifies an adult varies from country to country as well. Does a person become a man if he travels to a country that marks adulthood at 16? Or does he become a man on his own terms? This is the nuance, the complication.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @MxAllanaMae @STRIPPUHANIKA Yes, ofc, but our brains don't physically transform from child to adult on our 18th birthday. We don't become a different person on that day. Growing up is a process. Man/tween/ child are identities, yes, but they're also markers of the passage of adulthood.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @MxAllanaMae @STRIPPUHANIKA It's confusing b/c 18 is an arbitrary line. You don't magically grow a different part of your brain on your birthday. We all mature at different rates. When I'm writing, I want to describe people as close to how I see them. Man/Woman signifies maturity that I don't see sometimes

name: Reese Piper

tweet: @Lizzy_Beth248 Bear Brook is fantastic! I don't think it questions misogyny enough, but it's still very good. Dirty John, Dr. Death, Broken Harts aren't about serial killers but are worth a listen. There's also plenty of docs on youtube about Golden State Killer. Also recommend The Imposter

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: We glorify detectives who catch these killers, but in reality, many killers run loose. Violence against women (especially violence against sex workers) is not taken seriously. The police are not out there protecting us.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: True, the Bear Brook Killer was discovered after his death by a few skilled detectives, but really it was a community effort. Many interent sleuths and genealogists pitched in to help find the identity of his victims.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: The Golden State Killer (who was an ex cop) was caught by ancestry dna; Elizabeth Smart was found by a citizen; The Green River killer was caught with the help of another serial killer.

name: Reese Piper

tweet: I know people think we need police to catch serial killers & rapists. But as someone who consumes a lot of crime podcasts, I can tell you most of the time the police do jack shit.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: Lastly, autistics assigned female at birth are transitioning are higher rates now because the world is waking up to the fact that autism is more than a little boy's disorder. This is something to celebrate, not pathologize.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: Gender is, of course, a category. That is why so many of us are nonbinary, trans, hyperfemmme, hypermasculine, agender, or performers. Gender grows with us. It can't be tethered to how we're assigned at birth b/c it goes against the fluid way autistic people experince world.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: Autistic people don't experience the world through categories the way neurotypicals tend to. Just as we struggle to filter out info to focus, we struggle to buy into rigid social structures that are supposed to define us.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: I hate to keep tweeting about JK, but it needs to be said: autistic people are more likely to transition because we don't experience gender in the same way as neurotypicals. The dual spectrums of autism and gender overlap because they are two sides of the same coin.

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: @hardlynormal I think the original concept by Arlie Hochschild was the way some workers are responsible for maintaining a positive and happy demeanor so their customers are in turn positive and happy and, thus, more interested in spending. It's a direct exchange of emotions for wage

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: Of course, waitresses & flight attendants do this but sex workers do this to the extreme b/c we're not given a base wage. We have to pretend to be happy AND exuberate desire and carefree vibes to convince them to spend money and to keep them spending money

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: Emotional labor occurs when a worker suppresses one's feelings (or evokes fake emotions) to portray themselves in a certain light that, in turn, will make the customer happy and calm so they spend money

name: Reese Piper
description: Freelance writer, stripper • #ActuallyAutistic •  Working on a memoir •  Rep’d @mina_hamedi
tweet: Been researching emotional labor for a screenplay I'm writing. It's amazing how sex workers are never brought up in conversation when our jobs require way more evoking and suppressing feelings than a flight attendant or a waitress https://t.co/6KoKFSSJk7
